local_clues.quote: squats are the king of poorly performed exercises do them wrong and instead of growing nice quads and glutes you'll feel aches and pains in your knees your hips and even your shoulders but follow these four easy steps and I guarantee your squats will feel better and grow your muscles far better than they ever have before
local_clues.clue: Introduces the concept that squats are often performed incorrectly, leading to pains rather than muscle growth.

local_clues.quote: step one setup your Anatomy will determine what your perfect squat looks like so it's important to find the right setup for you and your body before you even get under the bar let's start with your footsteps hold the light weight at your chest set your feet hip width apart and squat down
local_clues.clue: Begins describing the initial setup for proper squat form, emphasizing individual anatomical differences.

local_clues.quote: see how that feels and make note of how low you should get then widen it by an inch or two and compare even the slightest modification can make a world of difference for knee and hip pain so keep going until you find what feels best
local_clues.clue: Suggests modifying foot positioning to alleviate knee and hip pain and find the most effective stance.

global_clues.quote: finally take a deep 360 breath into your waist as if you're trying to expand all sides of a weight belt and then brace your core as if you just coughed really hard at this point you should feel your legs core and lats all working
global_clues.clue: Emphasizes the importance of core bracing and engaging multiple muscle groups for squat stability.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Highlights the role of proper breathing and muscle engagement for achieving correct squat form, reinforcing the setup instructions.

global_clues.quote: what start with the lower body screw your feet into the ground as if you were trying to touch your heels together then level your pelvis with the floor by tilting it back
global_clues.clue: Describes correct lower body positioning and engagement for squat form.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Relates to the segment's focus on finding the right foot positioning and setup for individual anatomy.

global_clues.quote: finally take a deep 360 breath into your waist as if you're trying to expand all sides of a weight belt and then brace your core as if you just coughed really hard at this point you should feel your legs core and lats all working you're ready for step three The Descent
global_clues.clue: Covers core bracing for stability during squats.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Relates to the need for stability and proper muscle engagement during squats, crucial for any setup.

global_clues.quote: failure to do this is why so many people have a really strong leg press but I have a much weaker and unstable squat
global_clues.clue: Explains the consequences of incorrect squat setup and form.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Reinforces the segment's emphasis on proper setup to avoid instability and ensure effective squats.

global_clues.quote: next grip the bar with your hands as narrow as you can without feeling pain in your wrists shoulders or elbows the narrower they are the more upper back tightness and stability you'll have when you squat
global_clues.clue: Provides guidance on gripping the bar for upper back stability.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Complements the segment’s details on foot and body positioning by addressing bar grip, crucial for overall squat stability.

logical_inferences.details: The segment continues to build on the importance of proper squat setup, with a focus on foot positioning and slight modifications to find the ideal stance. This tailored approach helps prevent pain and enhances performance.

local_clues.quote: set your feet under the bar bend your knees to get under it and then place the bar on your upper back but avoid placing it too high on the little bony bump at the base of your neck
local_clues.clue: Describes how to correctly position the body and barbell before starting a squat, emphasizing bar placement.

global_clues.quote: next grip the bar with your hands as narrow as you can without feeling pain in your wrists shoulders or elbows the narrower they are the more upper back tightness and stability you'll have when you squat
global_clues.clue: Provides guidance on gripping the bar for upper back stability.

global_clues.quote: finally to keep you balanced as you squat spread your weight evenly over your foot by making sure each foot has three solid points of contact with the ground your big toe your pinky toe and your heel
global_clues.clue: Explains how to distribute weight evenly across the feet to maintain balance during squats.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Complements the segment’s focus on correct positioning by adding details on weight distribution for stability.

local_clues.quote: pull yourself down into the squat using your hamstrings let your butt drop down between your heels and push your knees out in the same direction as your toes
local_clues.clue: The individual is advised to pull themselves into the squat using their hamstrings, ensuring the butt drops between their heels while pushing knees outwards.

global_clues.quote: keep your upper back tight by pulling the bar down and continue lowering as deep as you comfortably can
global_clues.clue: Maintains the importance of keeping the upper back tight and lowering with control.

global_clues.quote: letting your knees go over your toes is perfectly fine
global_clues.clue: Debunks the myth that knees should not go over toes.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Provides reassurance that if the individual's knees pass their toes while adhering to the form in this segment, it is acceptable.

global_clues.clue: Emphasizes the importance of knee alignment.

local_clues.quote: if you use a narrower stance you should be able to get a little bit deeper if you use a wider stance it'll be closer to parallel
local_clues.clue: The stance width affects the depth of the squat, with a narrower stance allowing for deeper squats compared to a wider stance.

global_clues.quote: for knee and hip pain so keep going until you find what feels best and enables you to squat the lowest

global_clues.quote: and The Wider The Stance you use the more your toes will have to turn out
global_clues.clue: Wider stances require a greater toe turnout.

logical_inferences.details: The segment suggests that the individual is being advised to experiment with different stance widths to find the optimal depth and form, emphasizing customization to individual needs.

local_clues.quote: but if towards the bottom of your squat your upper body falls forward or your heels come off the ground or your lower back rounds excessively into Butt Wink these are all signs that you're not yet ready to go that deep
local_clues.clue: Indicators such as upper body falling forward, heels lifting, and excessive lower back rounding signal that the person may not be ready for deep squats.

local_clues.quote: the most common reason is the limited ankle mobility in this case try elevating your heels onto weight plates and see if that helps
local_clues.clue: Limited ankle mobility can be addressed by elevating the heels onto weight plates.

global_clues.quote: this is the most important part of the movement for growth so force your muscles to work by controlling the weight down and pausing at that bottom position for half a second
global_clues.clue: Highlights the critical nature of the bottom position for muscle growth and control.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Reinforces the advice on maintaining control and stability at the bottom of the squat.

global_clues.quote: everyone's bodies are different to maximize growth and prevent injury it's important that you find the right exercises and the right form for your individual structure
global_clues.clue: Emphasizes individuality in finding the correct form.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Supports the notion that the segment advises adjustments based on individual limitations, such as ankle mobility.

logical_inferences.details: The segment highlights potential issues like ankle mobility and suggests practical solutions, indicating the individual's form can be improved by addressing such limitations.

local_clues.quote: although both groups had similar growth in the quads the glutes and abductors grew significantly more in the Deep squat group so your goal should be to squat down to at least somewhere close to parallel if you use a narrower stance you should be able to get a little bit deeper if you use a wider stance it'll be closer to parallel
local_clues.clue: Mentions the depth of the squat, comparing narrower and wider stances to parallel.

local_clues.quote: if towards the bottom of your squat your upper body falls forward or your heels come off the ground or your lower back rounds excessively into Butt Wink these are all signs that you're not yet ready to go that deep and there's two main reasons for this the most common reason is the limited ankle mobility in this case try elevating your heels onto weight plates and see if that helps the other reason is a weak core and glutes in this case you can try out a more stable exercise like Smith machine squats before progressing to the barbell
local_clues.clue: Addresses common issues that can arise during squats, such as falling forward, heels lifting, or excessive rounding of the back (Butt Wink), and suggests solutions for them.

local_clues.quote: one study tested this by using a wooden barrier to prevent the knees from going over the toes while there was a bit less pressure on the knees when compared to letting them travel over the toes the stress on the hips and lower back significantly increased so as long as your knees don't cave in or out and instead push out in the same direction as your toes letting your knees go over your toes is perfectly fine
local_clues.clue: Explains the impact of knee position during squats, suggesting that letting knees travel over toes is acceptable as long as they don't cave in or out.

local_clues.quote: now once you reach that bottom position do not just let gravity drop you into that last introduce research suggests this is the most important part of the movement for growth so force your muscles to work by controlling the weight down and pausing at that bottom position for half a second
local_clues.clue: Highlights the importance of controlling the weight during the descent and pausing at the bottom position before moving to the ascent.

global_clues.quote: step three The Descent pull yourself down into the squat using your hamstrings let your butt drop down between your heels and push your knees out in the same direction as your toes keep your upper back tight by pulling the bar down and continue lowering as deep as you comfortably can
global_clues.clue: Detailed instructions on how to descend into the squat properly.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Provides detailed steps on how to properly perform The Descent which aligns with the observed suggestions and corrections in the segment.

global_clues.quote: creating whole body tension now at this point you do not want to just squat down you need to First activate several key muscles that will protect your back and keep you strong as you squat down failure to do this is why so many people have a really strong leg press but I have a much weaker and unstable squat
global_clues.clue: Emphasizes the importance of activating key muscles for stability during squats.
global_clues.relevance_to_segment: Supports the points made in LC2 and LC4, reinforcing the need to stabilize and control the body during squats.

global_clues.quote: it should be placed right onto the meat of your traps next grip the bar with your hands as narrow as you can without feeling pain in your wrists shoulders or elbows

The detailed descent and knee positioning instructions (LC2, LC3) indicate that the person demonstrates proper and improper forms regarding depth and stance.

The segment identifies common form issues such as upper body falling forward, heels lifting, and lower back rounding (LC2). The solutions offered imply these mistakes are being demonstrated and corrected.

Emphasis on controlling descent and muscle activation (LC4) points to a demonstration of how to properly control the movement and the importance of muscle engagement. GC1 and GC2 underscore this need, aligning with the overall instruction tone.

Discusses the importance of proper knee position (LC3). The mention of knees caving in or out highlights common errors. The relevance of GC3 supports the attention to balance and avoiding strain on hips and lower back.

local_clues.quote: the most common mistake people make here is shooting their hips back and letting their upper body fall forward this puts a lot of pressure on the lower back we want the chest and hips to rise at the same rate to do this drive up out of the Bottom by pushing the floor away and thinking about driving your traps up against the bar
local_clues.clue: Highlights the common mistake of letting the hips rise faster than the chest and how it negatively impacts the lower back.

local_clues.quote: keep your glutes engaged by keeping your knees in line with your toes rather than keeping them in continue pushing down against the floor and getting tall until your legs are fully extended
local_clues.clue: Stresses the importance of engaging the glutes and proper knee alignment to maintain form and balance throughout the squat ascent.

local_clues.quote: but as you come to the top avoid letting out a big exhale instead we want to maximize the pressure in your abdomen to protect your back and you can do this by keeping your lips held tighter together as you breathe out to gradually let air out
local_clues.clue: Explains the breathing technique required to protect the back during the ascent.

local_clues.quote: take another deep 360 breath in brace and repeat for another rep congrats my friend you have just done the perfect squat you can give this video a watch next to learn how to properly deadlift without hurting your back and I'll see you next time
local_clues.clue: Concludes by congratulating the viewer on completing a perfect squat, hinting that all steps have been properly executed.

global_clues.quote: pull yourself down into the squat using your hamstrings let your butt drop down between your heels and push your knees out in the same direction as your toes keep your upper back tight by pulling the bar down and continue lowering as deep as you comfortably can
